The referee and one of his assistants both point at the corner flag.

45:59 Caption: Well, a decent first half here. It's certainly not boring, but not the best match either. Neither team has really been able to control the flow of the game. The home team makes a lot of passes and attempts to maintain possession. The same goes for the away side.

44:34 Caption: The resulting set piece, sent into the penalty area by Ever Banega (Sevilla), was easily dealt with by one of the defenders.

47:59 Caption: It was a very watchable match. Great goals and there was plenty of action at both ends of the pitch. No regrets about following this game. Both teams tried unsuccessfully to control the game. Their overall performances were more or less even. Both teams attempted to play possession football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
Borussia Monchengladbach came away with a commanding 4-2 victory against Sevilla in a riveting encounter that held the spectators on the edge of their seats. The match took place amidst a vibrant atmosphere, with an attendance of 45,177 fans eager to witness this thrilling contest. Here's a detailed breakdown of how the action unfolded across both halves of the game.

**First Half**

The game got off to an immediately high-octane start. Sevilla kicked things off at the 2-second mark, with early possession causing the ball to go out of play within the first 16 seconds and another throw-in by Sevilla quickly following at the 26-second mark. Borussia Monchengladbach quickly gained momentum, as evident from their first shot on target just after the one-minute mark, followed shortly by another shot, forcing the ball out of play multiple times as both teams struggled to control the early tempo. By the three-minute mark, Monchengladbach had their first attempt off target, leading to a corner kick, which they couldn't capitalize on.

Sevilla’s defense was tested frequently. Monchengladbach's regular shots on target kept Sevilla's goalkeeper, Sergio Rico, alert. By the seventh minute, Monchengladbach had already amassed several shots on target, but Sevilla responded quickly, with their first shot on target at the eight and a half minute mark. Unfortunately for the visitors, it only resulted in a corner.

Midway through the first half, Monchengladbach’s Ibrahima Traore had to leave the pitch due to a serious injury, which forced manager Andre Schubert to bring on substitute Josip Drmic in the 13th minute. Despite this setback, the hosts continued their relentless advance.

Monchengladbach persistently put pressure on Sevilla’s defense, making several attempts to break through, as illustrated when Lars Stindl narrowly missed the goal after connecting well with a cross from Raffael in the 23rd minute but saw his effort go over the crossbar. Sevilla’s Evgen Konoplyanka remained a threatening presence, creating opportunities, yet repeatedly his attempts were intercepted expertly by Monchengladbach's defense. Yann Sommer, Monchengladbach’s goalkeeper, demonstrated exceptional skill with a crucial save to deny Konoplyanka in the 18th minute.

The opening goal finally arrived in the 28th minute when Granit Xhaka made a superb play, feeding Lars Stindl who made no mistake, tapping the ball into an empty net to make it 1-0. Sevilla attempted to respond but were constantly thwarted by Monchengladbach’s resolute defense. Ever Banega's dangerous low pass in the 31st minute couldn't find a precision enough to break through Monchengladbach's ranks. Despite Sevilla’s concerted efforts, the hosts maintained their narrow lead as the first half came to a close.

**Second Half**

The second half kicked off with Monchengladbach resuming their aggressive play. Almost immediately, there was a foul by Monchengladbach leading to an indirect free-kick for Sevilla in the first minute of the resumed play. Monchengladbach’s Oscar Wendt shortly thereafter missed a promising long-range shot that narrowly went wide of the right post.

Sevilla launched a series of their own offensives, with Ever Banega’s shot on target in the 3rd minute being expertly saved by Yann Sommer, who consistently proved his mettle throughout the match. Subsequently, Monchengladbach demonstrated their precision and skill once again. In the 23rd minute of the second half, they netted their second goal. Fabian Johnson was set free in the area by Julian Korb and finished expertly into the right side of the net, making it 2-0.

Unai Emery, recognizing the need to alter the dynamics on the pitch, made several substitutions. Michael Krohn-Dehli was replaced by Steven N'Zonzi around the 18th-minute mark of the second half. Shortly thereafter, another substitution saw Fernando Llorente replace Kevin Gameiro.

Despite Sevilla's strategic shuffles, Monchengladbach kept their momentum. Raffael scored Monchengladbach’s third goal around the 32nd minute, picking up Lars Stindl’s pass and slotting it effortlessly into the net, leaving the goalkeeper with no chance. The scoreline now read a formidable 3-0.

Sevilla managed to pull one back just a minute later. Fernando Llorente made an astute run, slipping through into the penalty area, feeding Victor Vitolo, who delicately chipped the ball past the keeper to register their first goal, now 3-1. The visitors tried to build on this momentum but struggled to find another quick breakthrough.

Monchengladbach were in no mood to let Sevilla take control. Lars Stindl, at the cusp of the 37th minute, latched on to a perfect pass and broke through Sevilla’s defenses, firing a shot past the keeper into the left post, making it an imposing 4-1.

Sevilla continued to push forward and were handed another lifeline in the dying moments of the game. Just around the 45th-minute mark, Granit Xhaka of Monchengladbach fouled an opponent inside the box leading to a penalty for Sevilla. Ever Banega stepped up to take the penalty and scored with ease, directing his shot inside the right post, altering the score to 4-2.

Despite their efforts to add more to the scoreline, Sevilla found Monchengladbach’s defense too robust to break down further. As the match drew to a close, Monchengladbach exhibited adept game control, keeping possession through short passes and orchestrating their movements meticulously.

In summary, Borussia Monchengladbach not only capitalized on their numerous opportunities but displayed defensive resilience when it mattered the most. Sevilla, despite their spirited attempts, found themselves largely outperformed by Monchengladbach’s cohesive unit. The home side’s blend of offensive prowess and tactical discipline ensured they departed the pitch as clear winners with a 4-2 scoreline, much to the delight of their fervent supporters. The match truly offered a spectacle, showcasing the competitive spirit and tactical interplay that make football such an enthralling sport to watch.
